channel.title: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
channel.description: Title may sound a bit weird lol. I want to learn C but without an IDE. I'll be using N++ to write the stuff but I don't know how to compile it. I also don't know how to actually run a C script so that could be a help if someone could just point that out... EDIT: Running W7 if that helps with the compilers. Thanks in advance...

item.title: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:36, topic:515053”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=633303.msg4297783#msg4297783 date=1368495168]

gui version is for lame-o’s.

sudo apt-cache search *

^ all you need imo

But apt-cache search doesn’t require root permissions, so you wouldn’t need sudo.
[/quote]m8, u obviously have never used *nix before. Every terminal command starts with sudo.

;)[/quote]

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“tigerclan, post:33, topic:515053”]gui version is for lame-o’s.

sudo apt-cache search *

^ all you need imo[/quote]

But apt-cache search doesn’t require root permissions, so you wouldn’t need sudo.

[quote=“Cres, post:34, topic:515053”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=633303.msg4297371#msg4297371 date=1368455984]
LOL using a terminal command isn’t ‘more programming oriented’, it just so happens that most/all linux distributions come with a package manager, which is used via the terminal. Some of them even come with a gui version.
[/quote]
I meant to imply the fact that it makes programming easier.[/quote]

Uhh?

item.title: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

That’s the point; I’m way too lazy to do things myself. And Linux distributions are much more programming oriented than I originally thought…
sudo apt-get install
The right click in a folder to open it in the terminal thing…
I honestly don’t mind the terminal because it’s actually fun to use

Read full topic
item.source: How do I set up my computer to program in C?

item.title: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:29, topic:515053”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=633303.msg4295439#msg4295439 date=1368132069]

You could have installed gcc on windows and do the same thing, lol.
[/quote]Still a bigger pain in the ass.

Cygwin is trivial to setup, so hardly a pain in the ass. Getting cygserver to setup, on the other hand, has given me a lot of grief in the past. Few people need to use that, though.

I COULD spend my time getting things to work on Windows but then again… Windows seems to be infamous when trying to make compilers work on it for several languages.
Linux-based OSs on the other hand provide smooth access to everything. I have both LinuxMint and Windows on my laptop now since Windows seems to do a better job at playing games.[/quote]

Well it depends on your flavor of access. Running a setup.exe and selecting features from a drop down menu is equivalently easy to using any GUI-based package manager on ubuntu or any other distribution of linux. If you’re more of a terminal person, then I would agree command-based package managers make life much easier than using a GUI. Either way, Cygwin has spent a considerable amount of effort making it trivial to setup on Windows. Given that it really helps for moving projects between Windows and Unix systems, I don’t see any reason not to have Cygwin setup on any Windows environment that may be used for development.

I know Clang can be setup just fine on Windows, too, but I haven’t done it so I can’t shed much light on that. Building it from scratch, however, is a whole other ballgame. I’m not sure if they provide Windows binaries or if you need to build it manually.

Read full topic
item.source: How do I set up my computer to program in C?

I COULD spend my time getting things to work on Windows but then again… Windows seems to be infamous when trying to make compilers work on it for several languages.

item.title: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

if you are just now starting to use C and want to use open source tools, use clang, not GCC. adding to what t4 said, put a Linux distribution on a small partition (fedora… ) and do your C work there.

item.title: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:15, topic:515053”][quote author=t4 link=topic=633303.msg4288368#msg4288368 date=1366766851]
Use vim, write a program, compile it with gcc using the command or an automated build environment like make/cmake/whatever. Use cygwin or a virtual machine.
[/quote]

Once a hipster, always a hipster.[/quote]
it’s not really being a hipster when the majority of all OSS C projects use the aforementioned.

item.title: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:5, topic:515053”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=633303.msg4278936#msg4278936 date=1365281820]

[quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=633303.msg4278919#msg4278919 date=1365281058]
Use Visual Studio C++ Express. You are making everything much harder for yourself by not using an IDE.
[/quote]He should learn how to do it without one.
[/quote]Why? That’s stupid and counter-productive. I began learning C# because of how useful Visual Studio and its intellisense is. There is absolutely no reason except arrogance or performance issues he should be avoiding an IDE.[/quote]
there are plenty of ‘programmers’ that can’t program without their ide.

[quote=“Whackatre, post:9, topic:515053”]tcc is a good lightweight compiler for windows. it’s also small and portable which is pretty cool.

by the way compiling C on windows generally sucks (it’s inferior at least compared to using *nix). [size=2pt]but if you’re using VS to compile then i guess that’s fine.[/size][/quote]
lmao

Read full topic
item.source: How do I set up my computer to program in C?
